data:
Generate a story and a one short sentence as a title in the journalism style. For the story you generate put the title at the first row. The story should involves the following entities and summary. Please make sure the story you generate is at least 500 words long.
Summary: Continue reading  Former Celtics great Paul Pierce gets ready before Game 3 of the 2022 NBA Finals at the TD Garden on June 8, 2022, in Boston. (Photo by Matt Stone/MediaNews Group/Boston Herald via Getty Images) Camped out in his Los Angeles home, Paul Pierce's television is frequently programmed to NBA games. While some retired players turn away from the sport that once commanded their lives, Pierce has stayed attuned to the league he played in for 19 seasons, hosting friends for marquee matchups and ordering piles of chicken wings. “I put in a big order because we usually got friends over, and we're watching some hoops.” Pierce will head to Houston next week for the first round of the NCAA tournament, watching games from inside a Buffalo Wild Wings alongside “All The Smoke” podcast hosts Stephen Jackson and Matt Barnes, plus two-time WNBA MVP A'Ja Wilson as part of an activation experience labeled “BnB-Dubs.” He has savored every avenue to remain connected to the sport, being part of the Showtime Basketball family after a run with ESPN. And rightfully so, you know what I'm saying?” The Boston Celtics' Paul Pierce shoots a layup in the first half of Game 3 of the NBA Finals on June 10, 2008, in Los Angeles. (AP Photo/Mark J. Terrill) There's a difference between older players telling you that behind the scenes and Charles being on national TV and everyone kind of airing out dirty laundry on podcasts. They've taken that maturity leap to finally take that next step and possibly be together for a long time and win multiple championships if healthy.” I know it was 10 years ago now, but do you remember where you were on draft night 2013 when you got traded to Brooklyn? The Blue Devils lost in the Elite Eight that season, but maybe they would have been champs if a long, athletic forward from Greece was on the team.With March Madness filling up our news feeds, online betting slips, and dreams (and nightmares) when we sleep, what better time to take a way too early look at the FanDuel Sportsbook odds for who will top the NBA Draft? After the game, Boeheim gave vague and opaque answers to questions about his future leading the program, and shortly after, the university announced he was being replaced by Adrian Autry. Twenty-year-old sensation Jenna Ortega is said to be securing a deal to star in director Tim Burton's “Beetlejuice 2.” The film is being written by Alfred Gough and Miles Millar, the showrunners of the hit Netflix series “Wednesday”—on which Burton is also […] NBC Sports Boston Celtics head coach Joe Mazzulla has a unique sleep technique, and he revealed the details to 98.5 The Sports Hub's "Zolak & Bertrand" show Wednesday.

Begin story:

Former Celtic Paul Pierce Keeps Close Ties with NBA While Watching NCAA Tournament at BnB-Dubs in Houston

Former NBA player and Boston Celtics great Paul Pierce remains closely connected to the sport he spent 19 seasons playing. Pierce, who retired in 2017, is currently camped out in his Los Angeles home frequently watching NBA games with piles of chicken wings and hosting friends for marquee matchups. Pierce's love for basketball will take him to Houston next week for the first round of the NCAA tournament, where he'll watch from inside a Buffalo Wild Wings with “All The Smoke” podcast hosts Stephen Jackson and Matt Barnes, plus two-time WNBA MVP A'Ja Wilson as part of an activation experience labeled “BnB-Dubs.” Pierce has embraced every opportunity to remain involved with the sport, such as  working with Showtime Basketball after concluding his run with ESPN. 

While watching the NCAA tournament games, Pierce is also keeping an eye on the upcoming NBA Draft, and has taken a liking to a certain Frenchman. "I'm hearing a lot of things about (Victor) Wembanyama. He's looking like he could be the No. 1 pick, you know what I'm saying?" he said during a recent interview with NBC Sports Boston. "A 7'2 kid that can do everything on the floor, that's a stretch five. And then you think about some of the top five guys, and I think Jaylen's gonna be right up there, (Kevin) Durant's gonna be there...but who knows who's gonna end up with that No. 1 pick."

While Pierce has been successful in making a seamless transition from playing to retirement by keeping a close involvement with basketball, Syracuse's basketball coach Jim Boeheim may not have such a smooth experience. Boeheim was relieved of his head coaching duties shortly after his team’s loss to Wake Forest in the ACC Tournament, leaving the fate of the program in the air. Boeheim gave vague answers to questions about his future leading the program, and University officials replaced him with Adrian Autry. 

Despite the uncertainty surrounding Boeheim and the Syracuse basketball program, 20-year-old actress Jenna Ortega is securing a deal to star in director Tim Burton's upcoming “Beetlejuice 2.” Ortega rose to stardom on the hit Netflix series “Wednesday,” which was produced by Burton. The director has kept busy recently, reportedly in discussions to direct a new live-action series based on the "Addams Family." 

Returning to basketball, Fox News reports that Brooklyn Net's star Kevin Durant is set to miss time with a hamstring injury, just before the NBA All-Star game. Durant is expected to miss two games with the injury, as the Nets continue to juggle injuries and play for a championship. Meanwhile, with the Suns currently on an 8-game winning streak, it remains to be seen whether they can maintain their current success and make a deep playoff run. 

In other news, a recent report indicates that Inland California, Illinois, New Jersey, and Delaware have the highest concentrations of the most-at-risk markets in the country in regards to the COVID-19 pandemic, with the biggest clusters in the New York City and Chicago metropolitan areas. The U.S. continues to experience a high rate of COVID-19 cases and deaths, with many areas facing new waves of infections. 

As Pierce soaked in the NCAA tournament games with a fresh batch of Buffalo Wild Wings, he reminisced about his draft night ten years ago when he was traded to Brooklyn. He also kept a close eye on the on-court performances of up-and-coming players, hoping to see the next big stars emerge. While the pandemic has caused many challenges for the sport and its fans, Pierce's love for basketball remains strong, and he continues to find ways to stay involved.
